factoid: Princess Mary addressed Lise saying "What is the matter with you, my darling? You look pale. Oh, you are very pale!"
Princess Mary ran up to her sister-in-law Lise in alarm.
A maid present suggested sending the midwife Mary Bogdánovna.
Mary Bogdánovna is a midwife from a neighboring town.
Mary Bogdánovna had been at Bald Hills for the last fortnight.
Princess Mary agreed to send Mary Bogdánovna and said "Oh yes, perhaps that's it. I'll go. Courage, my angel."
Princess Mary kissed Lise before leaving the room.
The little princess had pallor.
The little princess had physical suffering.
The little princess had an expression of childish fear of inevitable pain.
The little princess began to cry capriciously.
The little princess began to wring her little hands with affectation.
Princess Mary ran out of the room to fetch Mary Bogdánovna.
Princess Mary heard "Mon Dieu! Mon Dieu! Oh!" as she left the room.
Mary Bogdánovna was on her way to meet Princess Mary.
Mary Bogdánovna rubbed her small, plump white hands with an air of calm importance.
Princess Mary said "Mary Bogdánovna, I think it's beginning!" while looking at Mary Bogdánovna with wide-open eyes of alarm.
Mary Bogdánovna said "Well, the Lord be thanked, Princess."
Mary Bogdánovna said "You young ladies should not know anything about it."
Mary Bogdánovna did not hasten her steps.
The princess asked "But how is it the doctor from Moscow is not here yet?"
Lise and Prince Andrew had sent a doctor to Moscow in good time and were expecting him at any moment.
Mary Bogdánovna said "No matter, Princess, don't be alarmed."
Mary Bogdánovna said "We'll manage very well without a doctor."
Princess Mary heard something heavy being carried by men servants.
Men servants carried a large leather sofa from Prince Andrew's study into the bedroom.
Men servants had a quiet and solemn look on their faces.
Princess Mary sat alone in her room listening to sounds in the house.
Princess Mary opened her door sometimes when someone passed.
Princess Mary watched what was going on in the passage.
Some women passing with quiet steps glanced at Princess Mary and turned away.
Princess Mary did not ask any questions.
Princess Mary shut the door again.
Princess Mary sat down in her easy chair.
Princess Mary took her prayer book.
Princess Mary knelt before the icon stand.
Princess Mary's prayers did not calm her excitement.
The old nurse Praskóvya Sávishna appeared on the threshold with a shawl round her head.
Praskóvya Sávishna hardly ever came to Princess Mary's room because Prince Andrew had forbidden it.
Praskóvya Sávishna said "I've come to sit with you a bit, Másha."
Praskóvya Sávishna said "Here I've brought the prince's wedding candles to light before his saint, my angel."
Praskóvya Sávishna said it with a sigh.
Praskóvya Sávishna lit the gilt candles before the icons.
Praskóvya Sávishna sat down by the door with her knitting.
Princess Mary took a book and began reading.
When footsteps or voices were heard, Princess Mary and Praskóvya Sávishna looked at one another.
Princess Mary was anxious and inquiring.
Praskóvya Sávishna was encouraging.
Everyone in the house felt the same as Princess Mary.
Because of superstition that fewer people know of it, everyone tried to pretend not to know.
No one spoke of the impending birth.
The ordinary staid and respectful good manners habitual in Prince Andrew's household were present.
A common anxiety, a softening of the heart, and a consciousness that something great and mysterious was being accomplished at that moment were felt.
There was no laughter in the maids’ large hall.
In the men servants’ hall all sat waiting, silently and alert.
In the outlying serfs’ quarters torches and candles were burning and no one slept.
Prince Andrew paced up and down his study.
Prince Andrew sent Tíkhon to ask Mary Bogdánovna what news.
Tíkhon was instructed to say only that "the prince told me to ask," and come and tell Prince Andrew her answer.
